message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy suggest a viral infection. The presence of palatine tonsil wall exudates and soft palate petechiae, as well as the macular rash, suggests infectious mononucleosis. Recent unprotected sex is not a risk factor for Toxoplasma infection or Streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute HIV infection does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The recent unprotected sex history suggests the possibility of sexually transmitted infections, but the symptoms and physical exam findings are not consistent with acute HIV infection or toxoplasma infection. The presence of exudates and soft palate petechiae might suggest streptococcal pharyngitis, but the presence of a macular rash on the trunk and arms and mild hepatosplenomegaly make infectious mononucleosis a more likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fever, sore throat, nausea, and fatigue with bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and palatine tonsil exudates suggest infectious mononucleosis. The erythematous macular rash on the trunk and arms and mild hepatosplenomegaly also support this diagnosis. Acute HIV infection would not typically have such a rapid onset of symptoms, and Toxoplasma infection would not present with the characteristic palatine tonsil exudates. Streptococcal pharyngitis may present with some similar symptoms but not with the macular rash and hepatosplenomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest infectious mononucleosis. The recent unprotected sex may suggest acute HIV infection, but the symptoms and physical exam findings are not consistent with that diagnosis. Toxoplasma infection and streptococcal pharyngitis do not typically cause the rash and hepatosplenomegaly that are seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the exudates on the palatine tonsil walls and cervical lymphadenopathy, indicate infectious mononucleosis. Acute HIV infection typically does not present with a rash and hepatosplenomegaly, while Toxoplasma infection typically does not present with sore throat and cervical lymphadenopathy. Streptococcal pharyngitis may present with sore throat and cervical lymphadenopathy but does not typically present with a rash or hepatosplenomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, the symptoms of sore throat, fever, nausea, and fatigue suggest infectious mononucleosis. The bilateral posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, palatal petechiae, and macular rash on the trunk and arms are all characteristic of infectious mononucleosis. The recent unprotected sex is not a specific indicator for any of the options given.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis, with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, palatal petechiae, and a macular rash. Recent unprotected sex may suggest acute HIV infection, but the symptoms are not specific enough. Toxoplasma infection may cause similar symptoms, but it does not typically cause a macular rash. Streptococcal pharyngitis would not typically cause hepatosplenomegaly or a macular rash.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest infectious mononucleosis. Acute HIV infection would take longer to present with symptoms and would not typically cause the rash described. Toxoplasma infection would present with different symptoms and physical examination findings. Streptococcal pharyngitis would not typically cause the rash, hepatosplenomegaly, or soft palate petechiae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis, such as fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and rash. The recent unprotected sex is not relevant to the diagnosis. Streptococcal pharyngitis may present with sore throat and exudates, but not with a macular rash. Acute HIV infection and toxoplasma infection do not typically present with sore throat and lymphadenopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination indicate infectious mononucleosis. Other options can be ruled out based on the absence of certain symptoms (e.g., HIV infection usually presents with more systemic symptoms than just sore throat and fever).
